5Oqa1Fag5eQ.channel_description: AboutKidsHealth is a health education resource for children, youth and caregivers that is approved by health-care providers at The Hospital for Sick Children. AboutKidsHealth empowers families to become a partner in their own health care by equipping them with reliable, evidence-based health information. It makes complex health information easy to understand for families, and makes it immediately available whenever and wherever they have questions about child health regardless of where they are in Canada or the world.
5Oqa1Fag5eQ.description:
The health care professionals at The Hospital for Sick Children provide information on reducing the #pain associated with #vaccines for #babies less than one year of age. The information in this video is based on scientifically proven research that your healthcare provider might not know about yet.

The pain of vaccinations can be distressing for babies and parents alike. This video provides parents with simple and effective tools to help reduce their baby's perception of pain. 

These methods fall into three groups: 
(1) What you can give -- topical anesthetics and sugar water 01:43
(2) What you can do  -- child positioning and #breastfeeding 07:12
(3)  How you can act  -- your state of mind and distracting your #baby 08:54

For more information, visit http://www.aboutkidshealth.ca/Article?contentid=989&language=English

Follow us:
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/AboutKidsHealth
Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/AboutKidsHealth
Pinterest: http://www.pinterest.com/AboutKidsHealth
5Oqa1Fag5eQ.title: Reduce the pain of vaccination in babies - Full Video
5Oqa1Fag5eQ.transcript: The information in this video is new. Not all health-care providers know about it. So feel free to share this video with your baby's health-care provider. We probably give 18 to 20 needles, sometimes more, in the first 18 months of life. Vaccinations are a routine part of a baby's medical care and keep babies healthy. But the pain of vaccinations can be distressing for babies and parents. And these negative experiences lead parents to delay or not vaccinate children. "I think she remembers last time she was here." "Is that possible?" The statistics would suggest that about 10% of people avoid immunizations because of fear of needles. Many parents do not speak up about their baby's pain because they don't know what they can do about it. "She was already worked up before it even started, because she remembered." In this video, we'll show you ways to reduce pain during your baby's vaccinations. They fit into 3 groups: What you can give: topical anesthetics and sugar water. What you can do: child-positioning and breastfeeding. And how you can act: your state of mind and distracting your baby. Combining the different methods together will lead to better results. Look at this baby's response to the needle. You'll notice there are minimal signs of pain. Observe the baby's body movements, facial actions and sounds. So, let's get started showing you how to use these methods so you can reduce pain in your baby during the next vaccination. Topical Anaesthetics. Hospitals all over the world use topical anaesthetics to reduce pain in babies. They dull the pain where the needle enters the baby's skin. In Canada, you can buy topical anesthetics at the drug store without a prescription. They're safe to use in all ages, including newborns. They're available as a cream, gel or patch. Most people have experience with them at the dentist's office. "Here we go!" "It's where the needles are going to go..." For babies under 12 months of age, the anaesthetic is usually applied to the upper leg, and for children aged a year or older, to their upper arm. You need to wait for topical anaesthetics to take effect. Maxilene takes 30 minutes to work, Ametop takes 45 minutes, and EMLA takes 60 minutes. If you expect to wait at the clinic, then you might want to apply them there, instead of at home. Just peel off the backing and stick the patch on the skin. If you are using the cream or gel, squeeze it out of the tube in a circular pattern on the dressing that's provided until it's about the size of a nickel. This is 1 gram of the anaesthetic, equivalent to one dose. And then put the dressing on your baby's skin. Make sure the edges are sealed so the anaesthetic doesn't leak out. Fold over one corner of the dressing onto itself so you have an edge to grab onto later to make it easier to take it off. If the dressing is not available, you can use plastic wrap. Just wrap it around the baby's leg or arm. Ask your doctor whether your baby is scheduled for one or more vaccinations so you know whether to apply the anaesthetic to one or both legs or arms. "Now, I'm going to put the time on there..." Make a note of the time you applied them, or write it directly on the dressing or patch with a pen so that you can make sure you remember to take them off at the appropriate time. Remove the dressing carefully, as it can get very sticky. If you pull it off too quickly, it may cause your baby discomfort, like when you pull off a bandage. Instead, pull the dressing out and away from the skin, slowly, while securing the opposite corner. The dressing stretches, and it will lift off the skin without causing discomfort. Then just wipe the skin with a tissue. You can use a washable marker to show where the anaesthetic was because sometimes you can't tell after you take it off. You might notice some changes to the colour of your baby's skin— either reddening or whitening. This is temporary and goes away after a few hours. Rarely, there can be a skin rash, which can be a sign of an allergic skin reaction. If that happens, ask your baby's health-care provider about using a different topical anaesthetic product the next time. Sugar Water. You can control your baby's physical pain during vaccinations with sugar water. There are many randomized control trials that have shown that sugar water seems to be an effective way of reducing pain. "What do you think?" Probably by a number of mechanisms. Whether it's just the taste that these little infants have in their mouth, which is distracting them, or whether there's some interference in the neurological pathways, it really seems to be effective. "Okay." You can make your own sugar water. Just mix a packet of white sugar, which is about one teaspoon or 5 mLs, in two teaspoons, or 10 mLs, of water. You can use distilled water or boiled water. You can use tap water in older infants if you know that the water in your area is safe for drinking. Put a drop at a time in your baby's mouth, about a minute or two before the needle, using a dropper, syringe or medicine cup. You can also dip a soother in sugar water and give your baby the soother to suck on during the needle. "Oh, good boy!" Be careful not to squirt the sugar water directly in the middle of your baby's mouth. This can cause your baby to gag or spit up. Instead, put it on the side of the baby's mouth, inside the cheek. Hospitals use sugar water to reduce pain in babies, even newborn babies. It is safe and effective, but only use this as a pain medicine, not as a general comfort or as a food. Breastfeeding. Controlling your baby's physical pain with breastfeeding. You can breastfeed your baby during vaccinations instead of giving sugar water. Breastfeeding is one of the best ways to reduce pain in babies. Babies benefit from being comfortable in their mother's arms the sweet taste of milk, and sucking. It is a very effective physical comfort for babies during painful procedures. Start breastfeeding your baby about a minute or two before the needle. And make sure there's a good latch. Then, continue to breastfeed your baby during and after the needle. Your baby's legs or arms can be exposed so that the needle can be given easily. Breastfeeding during vaccinations is safe. There is no evidence at all that babies will gag or learn to associate their mothers with pain. If you cannot breastfeed, hold your baby and give sugar water with or without a soother. Baby's position. Your baby's body position during vaccination can affect how much pain your baby feels. Holding your baby upright can reduce your baby's pain during vaccinations. You can hold your baby in different ways: Facing you, chest to chest. Or hold your baby facing sideways. You can stand or sit or lean against the examination table. In all cases, providing a hugging hold and exposing your baby's limbs for the needle. If the needle is going into your baby's arm, make sure the arm is exposed, holding it firmly but gently so that your baby won't move it. baby's thigh, make sure the thigh is exposed, bracing it gently but firmly for the needle. Babies should always be held during injections. "I'm right here." Before, during, and after the needle. Try to avoid leaving babies on their back, held down, or without parents, as this can make them afraid, which can increase their distress during vaccinations. And we've shown in studies that infants who are held by the mother—that there's significantly less pain. So it makes sense that you should be holding, the mother should be holding, the caregiver should be holding, their infant at the time the vaccine is given. "Hold their hand." "Shhh, shhh." Discuss different positioning options with your baby's health-care provider and practise ahead of time. Try not to use too much force when holding your baby, as this can increase your baby's distress. Controlling pain during vaccination with your state of mind. Be there for your baby. Having a parent there makes a baby feel more secure. During vaccinations, be calm, use your normal voice, and be positive. This will make it better for your baby. Your baby looks to you for how to act and feel, so you can make it better or worse. If you are stressed, your baby will pick up on that, and that will make your baby more stressed too. One of the best ways to quickly become less stressed is to take a few deep belly breaths while holding your infant. Your baby will feel your rhythmic breathing, and this alone is very calming. Simply take a slow, deep breath through your nose, for 3 seconds, counting to yourself: "1... 2... 3..." And breathing so that it's your belly and not your chest that expands. And then exhale through your mouth for 3 seconds, counting: "1... 2... 3..." Take 3 breaths like this while cuddling your baby. The way the mother smiles, the way the mother holds the baby, the way the mother talks— what's the tone of the voice? Sometimes it's a language they use. "Not yet, not yet." During distressing times like immunizations, the best thing to do, after you let them know that you are there for them by bringing them close, is to talk about anything but the needle, or the pain, and with a normal tone of voice. Even if your baby doesn't understand your words, they understand your tone. "Oh my. I know. That was kind of annoying, wasn't it?" "Now you want to get down and play." "You want to play with your brother and do bubbles." Distract your baby. Controlling your baby's pain during vaccination with distraction. Your baby's activity during Distract your baby with singing, talking, or sucking. You can distract an older baby with toys too, such as: bubbles, pop-up books, rattles or smartphones. Distracting your baby can only happen when they are ready to be distracted. Trying to distract when your child is not ready will cause them to become even more distressed. If your infant isn't ready, just return to cuddling for a little longer. You can try distracting your baby with toys again sometime between 20 seconds and 1 minute after the needle. The way you distract your baby once may not work the next time. Be prepared to change what you are doing. Children have a right to the most comfortable experience possible. during vaccinations is important. Not all babies experience vaccinations the same way, but these methods can help all children to have less pain. Make a goal for your baby's next vaccination so you can plan to take any supplies you need, like topical anaesthetics or sugar water, and practise ahead of time. Talk to your baby's health-care provider about what you want to do. And remember—combine the different methods for the best results. "You're in no pain, no pain. Yaaay!"

CTj_xoCuhPU.description: Why do some parents reject vaccines, despite evidence that they've helped generations of children stay healthy? When sociologist Jennifer Reich started interviewing parents about this growing trend, she realized it wasn't as simple as being ignorant or anti-science. In this fascinating talk, she explains why this movement is the symptom of a much bigger problem -- our broken beliefs about parenting & health. Jennifer Reich is Professor of Sociology at the University of Colorado Denver. Her research examines how individuals and families weigh information and strategize their interactions with the state and service providers, particularly as they relate to healthcare and welfare. Over the last decade, she has examined how parents come to reject vaccines for their children, in dialog with physicians, complementary healthcare providers, activists, and researchers. She wrote Calling the Shots: Why Parents Reject Vaccines. She & her husband have three children. This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at https://www.ted.com/tedx
CTj_xoCuhPU.title: What I learned from parents who don't vaccinate their kids | Jennifer Reich | TEDxMileHigh
CTj_xoCuhPU.transcript: Transcriber: Eunice Tan Reviewer: Tanya Cushman So I gave birth to my second child about a year after 9/11, when our fear of terrorism was the highest we had ever known. It was the first year of the so-called "war on terror," and we had a brand-new Department of Homeland Security. At one particularly panicked moment, we were all advised to go out and buy duct tape and plastic sheeting so we could seal our doors and windows in case of a bioterrorist attack. We were told to be prepared at all times, that the air could become poisonous and that infectious diseases could be weaponized against unsuspecting communities. The last stores of smallpox in a handful of labs around the world seemed an obvious choice. And so first responders, which included my husband, Dave, and my friends in my Health Policy Fellowship, were asked to be vaccinated against a disease that was eradicated in 1969. At the same time, as a mother of a newborn and a three-year-old, I was online, reading advice from other mothers: how to find childcare, how to make breastfeeding easier, how to get your baby to sleep. But among all the usual motherly advice, there was an unusual trend: mothers suggesting that you don't actually need vaccines against childhood illnesses and that, in fact, they might be dangerous. So here I was, on the one hand, watching as mothers said you don't really need vaccines against known diseases, like whooping cough and measles, and on the other hand, while healthcare providers I knew were debating getting vaccinated against a hypothetical risk. And while I was trying to make sense of all of this, Dave would come home from the children's hospital where he worked and tell me stories about children with vaccine-preventable diseases: babies on ventilators with whooping cough, a child paralyzed with tetanus. These contradictions seemed hard to understand. And so as a sociologist, I set out to study this the way I would any other project, to try to understand why parents were rejecting vaccines despite evidence that they've helped to keep generations of children healthy. I set out to interview parents, which turned out to be mostly mothers because women make most of the healthcare decisions for their families. We talked about their fear of vaccines and the harms they were afraid they could cause. They told me about their distrust of pharmaceutical companies and the government agencies that are supposed to monitor them. Some told me infection actually is normal and natural and that the body can heal itself so long as it's healthy. But throughout, mothers told me how hard they're working: making baby food from scratch, dyeing Halloween cookies with crushed semolina and beets to avoid artificial colorings, growing organic food in their backyards. These mothers were working hard to do what they thought was best for their own children, and that included avoiding vaccines. Now, it's easy to dismiss these mothers as ignorant, selfish, or delusional, to say that they just don't understand how serious vaccine-preventable diseases can be, or to label them as anti-science. And if you're like most Americans, you already have firsthand experience with these conversations on Facebook, at particularly contentious Thanksgiving dinners, (Laughter) hopefully not, but maybe on your children's playgrounds. And while I disagree with their claims and have fully immunized my own three children, what I've come to understand in the course of my research is that parents who reject some or all vaccines are actually responding in ways that are pretty logical to the pressures placed on parents today, and that this movement is actually a symptom of a much larger problem. So let me explain. Think about what we tell women from the moment they're pregnant - sometimes even before conception - and throughout their children's lives about what it means to be a good parent. From birth plans to food to school choice to college admissions, we mothers are told that our children's successes or failures rest on our hard work. We can see this culture of individualist parenting in the way we blame mothers for anything that goes wrong with their children. Your child's sick, your child gets bad grades, your child's poorly behaved? It's probably your fault. And when you fail to make perfect choices, someone will let you know because others are watching. When I was pregnant, I was stopped, not once, but twice, while ordering coffee by other women who wanted to make sure I was ordering decaf. And we know that for low-income mothers and mothers of color, the pressures are much, much worse, resulting not just in dumb questions but sometimes in reports to social service or law enforcement agencies. But we don't just scrutinize mothers. We also don't believe that there's enough resources for everyone's children to succeed: not enough room at the good school, not enough spots on the traveling soccer team, not enough jobs after college. And so we pit parents against each other, competing for what seems like a small pool of resources, trying to do what's best for their own children. In this light, the recent college admissions scandal starts to make sense. They paid a high price to try to ensure their kids could be successful in a world where there doesn't seem to be enough to go around. But our problem is not just individualist parenting; it's also what we tell each other about what it means to be healthy. Public health agencies, physicians, websites, blogs, magazines, apps, your watch, friends, even family will tell you that health is a personal project. It is your job to stay healthy. Count your calories, count your steps, eat less fat, eat less sugar, drink more water. I don't remember what we're supposed to do with carbs, but something with carbs. When we hear that someone we know is sick, we almost always wonder what they did or failed to do that led to that illness. And the truth is that most of illness is beyond individual control. Some of it's genetic, much of it's environmental, and some of it's just bad luck. But we don't act that way. We act like if you make all the right decisions, you can stay healthy. If we put these two trends together - one that says it's your personal choices as a parent that determine if your child is successful and one that says that determine health or illness - it's really not that surprising that an increasing number of parents see vaccines as a personal choice and one that's part of a broader strategy for their own families. But our personal choices affect others in significant ways. Vaccines work best when everyone uses them. Yes, there is almost always personal benefit for the person who gets it, but their real power lies in lowering risk of infection for everyone in the community. So take something like rubella, the most easily forgotten component of the measles, mumps, rubella - MMR vaccine. Rubella is a fairly mild disease for virtually everyone who gets it. But it was a leading cause of birth defects when pregnant women would become infected. And so we immunize young children against rubella not because they most personally benefit, but because they're most likely to be around pregnant women who most need protection. Our best public health interventions and social programs have come from the belief that we can do more together than we can alone. Free public education, sanitation, national parks, even fire stations are all examples of things we collectively fund and support but might not equally use and benefit from. And the same is true of vaccines, but we seem to have lost sight of that. Instead, pharmaceutical companies tell us that our daughter could be one less woman with cervical cancer if we use their vaccine, and public health agencies tell us we can show our love for our own children if we immunize them. Throughout, vaccines get referred to as a consumer product and not a public good. And so, like all consumer products then, it's up to you to decide if you need it, if you want it, or if you'll benefit from it. More generally, we tell young families today that they should support to the limits of their resources but that they don't need to worry about other people's children - just their own. None of this is making our communities better. This is what I was talking about when I said that vaccine refusal is a symptom of a much larger problem. Because this culture of individualism is a crisis, and it affects most of the social problems we face as a society. Because if your child has access to clean drinking water, do you really care if the kids in Flint, Michigan, don't? And if your child has access to lots of nutritious food, does it really matter if the kids in the next town live in a food desert? And if your child can get access to a charter school, if your neighborhood school is failing and can't pay its teachers a fair wage? We could solve all these problems if parents just stood up and said, "Not my child, and not your child either." (Applause) We have to start dismantling this culture of individualist parenting. The first step is let's stop blaming each other for everything that goes wrong, particularly because so many things are beyond individual control. So when we meet a mother of a child with disabilities, let's not ask or even wonder what she did wrong during pregnancy. Just like when we meet somebody with cancer or heart disease, it doesn't really matter how healthy their lifestyle is or isn't. Let's just support them anyway. And let's find ways to help mothers who are struggling. Let's just give them a friendly smile sometimes or a word of encouragement, and yes, even when their children are screaming at the grocery store or on an airplane. Most importantly, let's find ways to show that we're invested in each other's children because - this is important - if we start acting like we're invested in other families, other families become invested in ours. Now, this won't solve the problem of declining vaccine rates overnight, but it will start to move us towards a culture of public investment in each other's health. And then we could build communities where everyone's children and parents can thrive. Thank you.

FXj6ELi4BVg.channel_description: AboutKidsHealth is a health education resource for children, youth and caregivers that is approved by health-care providers at The Hospital for Sick Children. It makes complex health information easy to understand for families, and makes it immediately available whenever and wherever they have questions about child health regardless of where they are in Canada or the world.

FXj6ELi4BVg.title: School Vaccinations – Improving the vaccination experience at school
FXj6ELi4BVg.transcript: Improving the vaccination experience at school: An educational video for public health and school staff Hi, I'm Leslie. I'm a public health nurse, and I'm going to talk to you about how to make vaccinations at school a positive experience for everyone: students, public health nurses, school staff and parents. This information is evidence-based. All the techniques are scientifically proven and recommended in clinical practice guidelines. School-based vaccination clinics are a convenient and efficient way of reaching youth to protect their health. By doing our best to help kids have a positive experience, we not only show students that we care about them, but we also promote vaccinations. Kids are more likely to get vaccinated in the future if they have a positive experience early on in the school setting. Anything that can help kids and promote health is something schools want to be a part of. Research shows us there are very specific things that can help make vaccinations a more positive experience. Many of these strategies are intuitive for nurses and already part of their practice. We've combined these strategies in a program called the CARD system. This is an approach to vaccination that promotes student-centred care and coping. CARD was designed with input from students, Each letter of the word CARD stands for a different category of evidence-based interventions that reduce pain, fear or fainting during vaccination. C stands for comfort; A stands for ask questions; R stands for relax; and D stands for distract. We modified policies related to our school vaccination program to make sure we were incorporating the principles of CARD at two specific time points: first, in our vaccine planning activities and second, during the day of vaccination. Let's review these steps together. Plan for the vaccination clinics ahead of time and work with school staff to secure appropriate spaces for vaccination clinics. The library is a popular choice. It has several advantages over other spaces. First, it can be blocked off to traffic, which minimizes interruptions. Second, it has large tables that can be rearranged for the clinic. Third, it usually has a private office or is near to one. This is important for students who want privacy. Fourth, a separate waiting area for students can be created right outside the library. This way, students are not watching others being vaccinated before it is their turn. It's ideal if you can confirm these spaces are dedicated for vaccination with the administrative staff of the school ahead of time. Also, try to pick a time in the morning. This minimizes a buildup of student anxiety in anticipation of the clinic and nurses' anxiety from having to rush if it is scheduled for later in the day. Next, educate students and school staff about CARD using CARD educational videos and pamphlets. Make an appointment for public health nurses to show the videos in the classroom. For some public health units, this can be done at the same time nurses visit schools to distribute the consent forms. If nurses are not present in the school, then share the videos and pamphlets with schools, and ask the staff to share them with the students. The videos are online, so they can be accessed by anyone who wants to view them. Then, have students fill out the preferred coping strategy on the student CARD pamphlet. Review these requests to plan upcoming clinics. For example, private room, presence of a support person or use of an electronic device as a distraction agent. Be sure the options are clear. For example, a student can have one friend to be their support person rather than a few. Store all this information in a safe place for future reference. On the day of vaccination, work with school staff to ensure the clinic setup minimizes visual cues that promote fear and the spreading of fear to others, known as fear contagion. For example, use a separate waiting area for students, set up tables and chairs to prevent students watching one another, use a table divider to prevent students watching needles being prepared and to also provide a reminder of CARD and have a distraction kit available with items like bubbles. Bubbles are always a big hit. Visit students in the classroom before the start of the clinic to introduce the nurses, review the clinic procedures and remind students about CARD. This helps to prepare for the procedure and build a rapport with the students. Identify students who are highly fearful and vaccinate them first. Also identify students with special requests, such as a private room or the presence of a support person and triage them appropriately. CARD will not make all students comfortable with vaccinations at school. There are some students with very high levels of needle fear that are not suitable candidates for vaccinations at school. These students will probably self-identify as such. Refer them to experts that can treat their needle fear. Then, they can be vaccinated after that. Use a student-centered approach to vaccination delivery. Remember that pain and fear are individual experiences. No one feels pain and fear the same way. Help students to play their own CARDs. This means inquire about their level of fear, ask them what cards they want to play and support them in their choices. Provide choices if they do not select specific strategies. Coach them through the procedures. Afterwards, ask students how they felt. Make sure to chart this information for future reference so it can inform the next immunizer. So, a few things that they can do is, you know, giving them the opportunity to choose looking away or looking at the needle, having a friend with them, having a parent with them, having some other sort of distraction like their phone or a book or a game. Those are the kinds of things that will help them get through that moment. Let's see how it works. And so, some kids are nervous about—are nervous about getting vaccines and others are not. On a scale of zero to three, zero being not scared at all or three being really nervous, how are you feeling? Great. What card are you gonna be playing today? Okay, and what did you bring for that? Oh, excellent. Are you gonna play a game or listen to some music? Okay, fantastic. So, I'm gonna get some things ready here. Relax your arm, and I can help you with that. Yeah, we want to make it, like, loose like spaghetti. All done. How was that? Fantastic. Get a band-aid... Let's see another example. Some kids get really nervous with vaccines and some kids aren't nervous at all. Let's say we had a scale of zero to three. Zero is gonna be the lowest. Where would you say you are on that scale? So, that's pretty high. So, you remember the CARD system that Kelly just went over with you as well. What kind of card are you gonna play today that's gonna help you with that? Nice. What kind of things you're gonna do to relax? Right, can you show me how you do that? Perfect. And what about distraction? Squishy? And I see you've brought a buddy with you, too. If the student brings a friend, ask the friend how they're going to help. So, you know what else can really help if your buddy blows bubbles. Do you like bubbles? Bubbles can be fun, so I'm gonna... have your buddy—what's your buddy's name? Brooke. Hi Brooke. Do you think you can blow some bubbles while I get things ready here? Deep breath. Oh, you're doing extremely well. One more, honey, and then you're done. Good job. You're completely done. What do you think? You did really really well. And thanks, Brooke, for helping out. Using the card system can make a really big difference. Everyone is prepared, and the clinics are far less chaotic. Students experience less pain, fear and dizziness. I think it really worked. It really helped having this with me, and I had a little distraction. I used the distract card by bringing in my Squishy. I also brought in my phone so I could play some games, and I used comfort by asking if I could just get two needles in my—in just the same arm. Um, well, being a buddy, like, it just really made me feel good because just knowing that, like, I'm helping someone that felt similar to how I felt, and just helping her, like, for the future and just, you know, giving her some confidence. My name is Tonni, and my daughter just had her grade 7 vaccines. Well, she has been very nervous about immunizations. She has been for many years, and, you know, I told her about— that there might be the CARD system, so we were just, you know, easing our way, working into trying something that we were hoping would be helpful to get her through the immunizations. So, when my daughter came home from school that day, I wasn't sure how the reaction would be, but when she came home, I could tell by the smile on her face, she was calm she was relaxed. I knew that it went well even before she even said anything. And when she did tell me how wonderful it did go, I was just so relieved and I was so proud of her and I could tell that she was proud of herself, as well. Asking students about fear is like addressing the elephant in the room, really, because we all have some level of fear or anxiety about something. It's just addressing the issue head-on instead of pretending like we're all coming from the same point because we clearly aren't. It's a great starting point to open the conversation. Kids know that we're empathetic and we know how afraid they are, and then that sets the stage for asking about the CARDs and coaching them. Using the CARD system just provides a framework to work within. So, as nurses, you already know what you're going to be doing with vaccinations, but it just puts it into a way— uh, organized way and runs the clinic very smoothly, that way. I really enjoyed my experience with the CARD system. I felt all the interactions with the students were fantastic. I love what I do, and this made it even better. The CARD system is not just about needles and needle pain. It's also about teaching kids ways to cope. They could use these same tools to cope with other stresses in their lives, whether it's a test, an assessment, something else going on at home. It can be used far beyond needle pain, but it certainly will help in the— in the vaccination process. Before the CARD system, we did have instances where students would experience significant anxiety. They weren't aware of their rights, their ability to self-advocate on behalf of themselves. The CARD system gives them that capability, and the hope is that with the implementation of the CARD system, that the kids will advocate for themselves and have a better experience through the vaccination process. With the schools, the teachers and the principals, the relationships we have with them are embellished because, through this process of working with CARD and providing informed consent, teaching with the students ahead of time, we are meeting their curriculum needs as well. The CARD protocol is simple, effective and research-based. The nurse in your school area is looking forward to helping your students make healthy decisions around their immunization and physical health. As educators, we too want students to make informed, wise decisions about their health. Here's a wonderful opportunity to work together with a common goal. Try CARD in your public health unit. You'll be amazed at what a difference it makes. Our nurses here say that once they learned about CARD, they can't go back.

Fcvgp6gNh6o.title: The Journey of Your Child’s Vaccine
Fcvgp6gNh6o.transcript: the journey of your child's vaccine a vaccine must be safe and effective how a new vaccine is developed approved and manufactured vaccines begin the journey in the laboratory where scientists work to figure out how best to protect against dangerous germs before a new vaccine is made available to the public researchers usually must do years of lab tests on the vaccine if lab results look promising and the vaccine appears to be both safe and effective volunteers will be enrolled to get the vaccines in a series of carefully monitored clinical trials the manufacturer usually conduct s-- three phases of clinical trials each phase is designed to gather more information about the vaccine safety and how well it works these trials can take years to complete during phase 1 about 20 to 100 healthy adults get the vaccine researchers tracked how well the vaccine works whether it's safe what is the correct dose for disease protection and what possible serious side effects may occur in Phase two hundreds of volunteers participate this is when experts learn more about the possible short-term side effects and how the volunteers immune systems are responding Phase three trials are the most informative with results from hundreds or even thousands of volunteers in these trials vaccinated volunteers are compared with volunteers who receive another vaccine or no vaccine these results give researchers a better idea of how well the vaccine works and if there are possible side effects they should expect the Food and Drug Administration or FDA along with the vaccines and related biological products advisory committee review all of the data the researchers have gathered throughout the trials and decide whether or not to license the vaccine once licensed vaccines are made in batches called blots manufacturers test the Lots to make sure the vaccines are safe pure potent the FDA reviews the safety and quality of each lot before it is released the FDA inspects manufacturing facilities on a regular basis to ensure quality and safety how a vaccine is added to the US recommended immunization schedule once the FDA licenses a vaccine CDC brings together the members of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices or ACIP to review all of the research available on the licensed vaccine the members of the ACIP include world-renowned vaccine and disease experts from groups like the American Academy of Pediatrics and the American Academy of Family Physicians CDC and other government agencies these experts look at how well the vaccine works and whether it's safe when given to different age groups they also weigh the seriousness of the disease the vaccine prevents and figure out how many children would get sick if they did not get vaccinated the experts then decide if they should recommend that vaccine be added to the u.s. recommended immunization schedule if the CDC approves the experts recommendations the vaccine officially becomes part of the schedule and soon it will be available at your health care providers office how a vaccine safety continues to be monitored once children start getting the vaccine the FDA and CDC continue to watch for possible side effects reactions that happen after a vaccination get reported to the vaccine adverse events reporting system or Tver anyone can submit a report to Tver including parents caregivers patients doctors and nurses however the reactions that are reported may or may not be caused by the vaccines they may require further investigation researchers at FDA and CDC analyzed the various reports and look for any trends that may be happening FDA and CDC also use other vaccine safety systems the vaccine safety datalink or VSD and the post licensure rapid immunization safety monitoring system or actively monitor new vaccines to obtain additional information about their safety VSD has access to health care information for over 24 million people prism can analyze health care information from over 190 million people CDC also uses the clinical immunization safety assessment project or sisa to study vaccine safety sisa is a collaboration between CDC and seven medical research centers sisa vaccine safety experts conduct individual case reviews and clinical research studies about vaccine safety recommendations for using the vaccine may change if the vaccines risks profound to be greater than its benefits the end goal is always the same to safely and effectively protect children families and communities against potentially serious diseases for more information please visit cdc.gov/tips vaccine safety or fda.gov /c ber

Mz11y9Cnnu4.description:
This is a short video on BCG vaccination.
BCG vaccine is given to prevent the serious complications of TB & Leprosy.It does not prevent Pulmonary TB.

BCG vaccine works for 20years.
BCG stands for Bacille Calmette Guerin.
BCG is a live attenuated freeze dried lyophilized vaccine.
It is derived from Mycobacterium bovis Danish 1331 strain.
Strenghth of the vaccine is 0.1mg in 0.1ml.
Diluent is Normal saline
Dose is 0.1ml for childern above 1 month age & 0.05ml for children below 1 month age.
BCG vaccination is done in the skin over the left deltoid intradermally by an OMEGA MICROSTAT 26G Syringe.
The site of vaccination goes through the stages of
PAPULE at 2weeks
ULCER at 4weeks
SCAR at 6weeks
Mantaux test becomes positive after 8-14weeks.
The major complications of BCG VACCINATION are severe prolonged ulceration, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis.

THANK YOU for watching our video.Feel free to watch the other videos in our channel.

If you like us PLEASE LIKE and SUBSCRIBE our channel.

Thursday - Another new dose about the wonders of the world.
Fridays - Learn the latest in science News.

Rzxr9FeZf1g.description:
Fewer children in the United States are getting vaccinated. That’s bad news for those kids, and also for public health in general. Often, the response is to argue and debate and get angry at people who are we see as making terrible, irrational decisions. Instead of doing that, let’s use science to understand why this is happening in the first place.

Hosted by: Hank Green
----------

Rzxr9FeZf1g.title: The Science of Anti-Vaccination
Rzxr9FeZf1g.transcript: We haven't commented on the "vaccination debate" here at SciShow, mainly because there's nothing to comment on.  Vaccination does not cause autism and saves millions of lives every year.  But there is a debate as to whether vaccination makes sense.  And a lot of people laugh at that, but we at SciShow aren't about making judgments,  we are here for science and how to use it to better understand the world.  We understand the anti-vaccination movement as a phenomenon that needs to be understood.  So instead of saying again how, yes, vaccination is right and no, it doesn't cause autism,  Let's prefer to use science to understand why fewer and fewer people vaccinate their children.  I'm Hank Green and this is a SciShow.  First, let's talk about where this supposed connection between vaccinations came from  and autism.  The number of diagnosed cases of autism is certainly growing. Many scientists believe that this is above all  or entirely due to the existence of more effective diagnostic procedures and changes in  how cases of autism are reported.  So while the number of diagnosed approaches to autism is growing, it is certainly not possible to say  the number of cases as such is growing. If so, it must be due to some environmental factor.  When we talk about autism, we're actually talking about a whole set of developmental disorders,  which may affect an individual's ability to communicate and socialize, or cause the development of patterns  behaviors that are quite specific and rigid.  The disorder can manifest itself in various ways, but you have probably heard of them  as about "autism spectrum disorder (ASD)"  Although ASD has been found to be strongly genetically determined, it appears  that environmental factors are also at stake.  And that's the core of the controversy - we just don't know exactly  what causes autism.  And in the absence of a clear explanation, people tend to find the explanation themselves.  And the way our brains do it is almost entirely through cognitive bias.  Cognitive distortion is basically anything that distorts the way we process and interpret new information.  There are clouds of different types of distortion / slope - some distortions cause us to ignore certain ones  data; others force us to place too much emphasis on certain data; they can even force us  focus on facts that are in fact irrelevant to what we are observing.  But basically when we hear the hypothesis and think, "Yeah, that makes sense!"  so what we're actually saying is, "Yeah, that corresponds to my cognitive distortion."  And so people justify autism with various things ... plastics, pesticides, use  antidepressants during pregnancy, GMOs, sugar, intestinal bacteria, and vaccinations. Basically  it starts with whatever makes the most sense to the person making the hypothesis.  The onset of autism typically manifests itself in one of two ways. Either parents notice a delay  in language development, typically around the first year. Or they notice the obvious  sudden loss of ongoing development, which can happen at any time until the third  People are pattern recognition devices. We need to be able to figure out what behavior  and strategies lead to positive results.  But even more than that, we try to find things that lead to negative results.  This overweighting of negative results is a well-known psychological effect called "negative."  distortion".  So imagine that you wake up one morning like this and your car doesn't work. Your brain will be  want to know what happened. Did you leave the lights on? You drove yesterday  a huge puddle and maybe something shorted? There must be SOME reason why he doesn't want to  start!  On the other hand, when you get into a 15-year-old car and it starts right after  what had the whole week to do to ride, you do not tend to ask "What happened well !?"  We spend a lot more cognitive resources on finding out why bad things happened than  on why good things happened.  In psychology, this search for an explanation is called "attribution" and  Different people have different ways of explaining styles.  Some people tend to blame themselves more, while others look for an external event,  which he blames. But one thing is clear: we are very bad at innocent of nothing.  Not surprisingly, parents of children with autism, especially those who notice  sudden losses of previous developments will look for a possible cause.  And if the most significant recent event concerning a child's health was vaccination,  which can be said about many moments in the life of a young American, we can call the vaccination  as a potential cause and consider it as a guide worthy of further investigation.  But that is perfectly logical. The problem is that over a dozen peer-review scientific articles  found no correlation between autism and the MMR vaccine or any other vaccine,  And yet, when you google vaccinations and autism, quite a number of search results claim that  there is a relationship between them and this relationship is kept secret either by the government  or large corporations.  Parents who are already struggling with frustration at the inability of doctors  to tell them why something like this happened to their child, they will find it live on the internet  a community of similarly frustrated people who share their values ​​and experiences.  These communities are full of stories that combine vaccination and autism.  And so, as expected, some people become convinced that they have found a reason  disorders of their child.  As soon as they decide, a confirmatory bias pops up. Confirmatory bias is simple  our tendency to receive easier, and with less control, information, and stories  worldviews that confirm our existing assumptions.  I repeat, it's completely natural and everyone does it. And indeed,  It has been shown that convincing someone that the presumption they believe is wrong is actually increasing  tend to believe the presumption.  And so a community is born and the safety of vaccination is questioned.  And as soon as the whole thing shifts from having the doctor tell you it's time to vaccinate your child  (and 99% of parents agree because the person studied medicine)  To question the need for vaccination, the vaccination rate of the population begins to decline.  A 2011 study showed that parents who are thinking about being vaccinated before their baby is born  they will have their child vaccinated 8 times less likely. In principle, this means  that when they have the opportunity to do their own research, what they find is confusing. And when you're confused,  so the standard choice is not to make any choice.  This is an example of another bias, which is called the omission bias.  In essence, we understand harmful activity as worse than harmful inactivity.  In fact, a frequently cited study found that when the choice of vaccination is conceived as an action,  The average parent will vaccinate their child only if the child is not vaccinated at least  TWO more dangerous than vaccinations.  This has to do with our perception of future regret. Parents say they will feel worse,  when they do something and harm their child than when they do nothing and  the child will be harmed by their inaction.  This perception of potential regret can be so strong that even just tossing over possibilities  action versus inaction seems counterproductive.  A 2013 study found that attempts to persuade parents to vaccinate their children did in fact  reduced the percentage of those who had their children vaccinated.  If vaccination is presented as a personal choice instead of a necessity for public health,  then potentially harmful inaction may seem more moral than potentially harmful  activity and vaccination rates of the population is declining. Parents choose to "let nature pass."  And, as might be expected, this effect is stronger in people with a measurable tendency to  "nature". It is simply a tendency to perceive things that come from nature as natural  less threatening than things we invent ourselves.  One way psychologically measures this tendency is to ask subjects if they prefer a substance  extracted with plants or synthesized in a laboratory, even if they are chemically identical.  And naturally, other people have deaths against big governments or corporations and these  considerations about vaccination fit well with such worldviews. Here again, confirmatory bias plays a role.  But even people who are not so prone are more likely not to have their child vaccinated,  if they start looking for information before their baby is born.  This is due to another human brain error. We are really bad at what psychologists do  they say "risk perception".  When there is the slightest likelihood that vaccination causes developmental disorders,  Parents will compare the disease they know, autism, with diseases they never know  they did not see.  Measles have not been much talked about since the 1970s. Measles does not scare people  my age for the same reason we're not scared of by a giant man-eating squirrel ... never  we didn't see her.  Risk perception is basically a science in itself. But it turns out to be vague  The future risk, such as the future probability of the disease, is far less frightening than  current specific risk, such as the sudden onset of autism.  So, surprisingly, the success of vaccines is one of the reasons why people leave less  vaccinate your children.  So yes, it turns out that people are complicated, and this is a complicated problem. People  They are adept at understanding the effects of resource selection - like anti-vaccination online  forums - and often completely unable to accept the fact that a negative outcome may simply be  the result of something that is completely out of their control - and still not well understood.  This is not an "anti-vaxxer" problem, it is a human problem.  Those of us who believe in science or understand statistics and bias / bias, simply  they had a different life than people who give more importance to stories or opinions  friends or strangers they meet online and who have similar views.  So the next time you're frustrated with the drop in vaccination in America,  remember that we can only lead this debate because of the dramatic success of vaccination,  and that anti-vaccination activists are run by exactly the same people  logical traps and cognitive distortion like any of us. Only by understanding  and by accepting these psychological traps, into which we so easily fall,  we will be able to solve this problem. And that's what science is about.  Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, where we really try to be objective.  And we objectively believe that the universe is amazing and fantastic. And if to us  You want to add along the way in his understanding and everything in him, including our brains, you can  Go to youtube.com/scishow and sign up for the cash on delivery.

SmWQqef-j6Q.description:
Paediatrician/Neonatologist Antonis Darzentas has seen children die of preventable diseases. In his talk, which delicately balances between scientific facts and emotion, he reminds us of the contribution that vaccination has made to public health and he addresses the 13 myths of the anti-vaccination movement.

Η αλήθεια για τα εμβόλια

Ο παιδίατρος/νεογνολόγος Αντώνης Δαρζέντας είδε παιδιά να πεθαίνουν από νοσήματα που μπορούν να αντιμετωπιστούν. Σ'αυτή την ομιλία που ισορροπεί ανάμεσα στα επιστημονικά δεδομένα και το συναίσθημα, μας θυμίζει την τεράστια συμβολή των εμβολίων στην δημόσια υγεία και απαντά στους 13 μύθους του αντιεμβολιαστικού κινήματος.

 Paediatrician-Neonatologist Antonis Darzentas writes articles for print and digital media, and also uses social media, to debunk persistent myths and misconceptions surrounding the practice of medicine, and in particular vaccinations. His interventions aim, among other things, to respond to the anti-vaccination movement in a clear and scientifically accurate way and to educate the public, especially after the recent measles outbreak in Greece and other European countries. Antonis Darzentas studied Medicine at the University of Patras between 1989-1995. He specialised in Paediatric Medicine at the University Hospital of Patras between 1999 and 2003 and then completed his sub-specialty at the Children’s Intensive Care Unit at Aglaia Kyriakou Hospital in Athens. In 2004 he joined the University Hospital of Patras as a consultant, initially at the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit and then at the Children’s Intensive Care Unit of the same hospital until 2008, when he opened his own practice. This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at https://www.ted.com/tedx
SmWQqef-j6Q.title: The truth about vaccines | Antonis Darzentas | TEDxThessaloniki
SmWQqef-j6Q.transcript: Translator: Chryssa R. Takahashi Reviewer: Ellen Maloney What is the most important medical development in modern history? Could it be open heart surgery? Organ transplants? Cancer treatments? According to the World Health Organization, it's none of the above. It's actually vaccines. Vaccines and clean water in developing countries are the most significant medical interventions in recent times. What is so fascinating about vaccines? Nothing, really, they are just shots. Those shots, however, have saved hundreds of millions of lives and continue to save three million lives each year. Let's take a brief journey through the history of vaccines. 500 years ago, smallpox and measles are introduced to Latin America by the Spanish conquerors, which kill more indigenous people than the armed conquistadores themselves. It seems that the Maya and Inca civilizations perished because of these two diseases. In Greece, just 100 - 150 years ago, the child mortality rate is around 50%. Half of all children die before they reach adulthood. Back then, the saying was: "We have many children because God is due His share." In the 20th century alone, smallpox killed 300 - 500 million people worldwide. Measles claimed 150 million lives during the same time. These two diseases together killed five to seven times more people than both World Wars combined during the same century. We do not include whooping cough, diphtheria, polio, hepatitis or the flu because we lack accurate records. In 1980, the World Health Organization announced that the world is free from smallpox. Thanks to vaccinations, the smallpox virus was completely eradicated from the natural environment. Polio has had a similar progression. Last year, we only had 37 cases of paralytic polio around the globe. A disease that has killed millions and caused permanent paralysis to millions of others, is fast on its way to being eradicated. This year might be the last time that we encounter polio victims. We will preserve these two viruses in a testing tube, in the depths of a laboratory, as a record of two of the most lethal microorganisms to have swept the planet, killing more people than all wars combined. Same case with measles. In 1980, measles killed 2.6 million children and adults worldwide. Last year, for the first time, there were less than 100,000 fatalities. Then the anti-vaccination suddenly fad appeared. While we see people queueing for life-saving vaccines, in the West, people are moving away from vaccines. Last year, we had a 400% increase in cases of measles in Europe, with more than 40 people dead. In the U.S., in 2012, there were more than 50,000 cases of whooping cough with more than 20 people dying from the disease. A recent survey showed that 24 % of Greeks are hesitant about vaccines, believing they cause autism. Other countries in the West have similarly high numbers of people doubting vaccination. People in developing countries have little to no doubt toward vaccines because they've actually seen people die from diseases that we, in the West, have forgotten. These diseases are forgotten thanks to vaccines. Let's see how the anti-vaccination movement started. In 1998, Andrew Wakefield, a British surgeon, published a study citing only 12 cases - I repeat only 12 cases - claiming that M-M-R, the combined vaccine for Measles, Mumps and Rubella, causes autism. Wakefield further claimed that this doesn't happen if those vaccines are done separately. This resulted in a huge anti-vaccine movement in countries of the West, promoted by large media groups and Hollywood stars. Independent investigation later proved that Wakefield had been illegally funded by lawyers that specialised in lawsuits against pharmaceutical companies, had tampered with the findings of his independent collaborators, and not only that, and had also patented a single Measles vaccine for future financial profit. At the same time, dozens of independent studies were carried out on thousands of participants disproved any association between the triple vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella, or M-M-R, and autism. Andrew Wakefield was fired from the hospital in which he practised and was stripped of his medical license, he could no longer practice medicine. But the damage had been done. Vaccines had acquired a bad reputation. Let us now answer a few simple questions to shed light on the most common myths regarding vaccination. Is natural illness better? Is it better for a child to contract a disease? Absolutely not. Even mild illnesses can considerably lead to serious complications like meningitis, encephalitis, pneumonia, that may lead to death in children or even adults. Furthermore, a recent study proved that a patient that contracts measles is subjected to immunological shock, that erases the immune system's memory for previously contracted viruses. For the next several years, these patients were found to be at risk of dying from another serious infection. Second myth: Vaccines burden the body with useless antigens and pressure the immune system. To be clear, an antigen is part of the microbe that can cause an immune response. That is also completely wrong: vaccines contain very few antigens, the minimum necessary to cause an immune response. In contrast, when someone contracts the virus in nature, they are exposed to tens or hundreds of antigens, sometimes triggering an autoimmune reaction. Third myth: Vaccines cause autism and other long-term complications. The answer to the first point was evident from the earliest studies, but, further than that, 40 to 50 years of mass vaccination programs worldwide, thousands of independent studies and millions of vaccinated individuals no long-term consequence caused by vaccines has been proven. Fourth myth: Vaccines have immediate and serious side-effects. Vaccines actually have mild side-effects. Serious side effects from vaccines are very rare and can be effectively treated by trained medical staff. It's safer to get a vaccine than to walk on the street, or smell a flower on a field. On a personal note, I calculated that in 20 years of being a practising pediatrician, I've administered more than 80,000 vaccine shots. During that time, not once did I encounter serious side-effect. Not one. Fifth myth: Can we vaccinate children at an older age? We can, but it would be a huge mistake. If we do that, babies and toddlers, who contract diseases more easily and develop serious complications more frequently, would be exposed to unnecessary danger. Sixth myth: I didn't vaccinate my child and he's fine. When the majority of a population is vaccinated they form a contagion barrier, that also protects unvaccinated individuals. When vaccination percentage falls, however, epidemics return, because diseases have the ability to spread, naturally starting with unvaccinated individuals. In Greece, this typically occurs within Roma communities that do not vaccinate, with patients dying very often of whooping cough or measles. Seventh myth: Vaccines contain harmful substances, like mercury or aluminium. 20 years ago, a mercury compound was used as a preservative agent in some vaccines. The so-called thimerosal, you might have heard about it. This was removed from vaccines after the relevant recommendation by the American Academy of Pediatrics, even though it had never been proven to be harmful. A little-known fact is that when you include seafood in your diet, you consume 100 times the amount of thimerosal than getting vaccinated. Same goes for aluminium: a baby that exclusively breastfeeds, in the first six months alone, will have consumed ten times more aluminium than all vaccinations combined. If the baby that does not breastfeed and receives formula milk instead, will have consumed 40 times as much aluminium in the same period. Eighth myth: Anti-vaccine websites present serious scientific facts. Allow me to read you something. "There is a substance that has flooded the human body. It contains formaldehyde, ketones, ethanol, tryptophan, urea, dihydrogen monoxide, large quantities of iron oxide, 20 further acids and 4,000 chemical substances. This substance can cause anaemia and leukemia; it also the route for cancer to spread. Pharmaceutical companies and governments spend billions of dollars to process and preserve it". Did all this scare you? I scared you by telling you the truth, with no scientific inaccuracy. But the substance I just described to you, the one that scared you, is human blood. That's exactly what happens with anti-vaxer websites. Confusing, pseudo-scientific terminology, laced with a lot of scaremongering that a regular reader cannot possibly discern and is drawn to the wrong conclusion. Ninth: Pharmaceutical companies have an agenda for population decrease, which they implement through vaccination. When vaccination programs started 50 years ago worldwide, the world population was at three billion. Today it is seven billion and is dramatically increasing, despite a rise in deaths from environmental pollution and heart disease caused by modern lifestyle. We really don't need to say anything more on this matter. Tenth myth: Pharmaceutical companies greatly profit from vaccines. This is one of the most popular anti-vaxer arguments. Vaccines, in reality, constitute less than 3% of earnings for pharmaceutical companies. Less than 3%. Vaccines require high technology and are difficult to distribute. On the other hand, just one day of hospitalization, in a regular or an Intensive Care Unit, can cost thousands of euros. The same amount could be spent on hundreds of vaccines. Every single study has shown that vaccines are cost-effective and do not burden public spending, they actually alleviate it. And that's the reason countries around the globe, prosperous and poor alike, offer vaccines to their citizens for free. Eleventh myth: Anti-vaxers are pure ideologists that are concerned with our well-being. Internationally and locally, anti-vaxers promote 'healthy' and 'alternative' treatments. This alternative market is huge, with a turnover close to those of pharmaceuticals. Many anti-vaxers abroad have become billionaires. Also in Greece, thousands make a living by selling fake and dangerous 'treatments'. It was revealed that Andrew Wakefield himself has received 500,00 pounds worth of illegal funding from lawyers that specialize in suing Twelfth myth: Diseases were eradicated thanks to better living conditions, vaccines had nothing to do with that. Again, this is completely wrong. We have many statistics. All statistical data show a dramatic drop in diseases after their equivalent vaccine was made available to the population. Characteristically, vast India which managed to wipe out polio just a few years after introducing its vaccine, despite no changes in public hygiene. If anything, hygiene was worse because of overwhelming mass urbanization. Same result in the U.S. with the haemophilus vaccine in 1993, but also worldwide. Before the vaccine, there were 20,000 cases per year. After the vaccine, less than 1,000 in just a few years. Exactly the same happened with pneumococcal and meningococcal diseases, worldwide but also in Greece. A large decline in disease cases. Canada has excellent public health records, that reveal the number of disease cases before and after vaccines. All diseases saw a decrease of 93% to 100%, that is near eradication. Of course, that works both ways: in the 1970s and 2010s, there was a noticeable drop in vaccination rates for whooping cough in western countries. Sure enough, there was an equivalent rise in cases and deaths. Another tragic, example is the latest measles outbreak in Europe. What happened and measles came back? Could it be worse hygiene? Of course not. Vaccination rates dropped. Thirteenth myth: I hear your point but I don't want to vaccinate my child. Since you are all vaccinated, why do you care? On one hand, a parent that does not vaccinate their child exposes them to serious and mortal danger. That is illegal. On the other hand, an unvaccinated child can transmit a disease to someone who could not get the vaccine because they are not old enough or for medical reasons. Immunosuppressed children and adults due to leukemia or an autoimmune disease are the first to contract a disease by people with incomplete or no vaccination at all. In Romania, out of the 40 people that died due to the latest measles outbreak, 30 were babies younger than one-year-old, the age of measles vaccination. In Italy, a child that had beaten leukemia thanks to chemotherapy, later contracted measles from their unvaccinated sibling and died. Pregnant women and their newborns are under the same category, both groups very susceptible to serious or untreatable damage from these diseases. When we do not vaccinate, we do not only threaten our own child. We threaten all vulnerable population groups. Not vaccinating is anti-social behaviour. It's like running a red light or driving in the opposite lane of the highway. Consequently, vaccines are the safest, most important and most cost-effective public health practice. Vaccines are among the greatest discoveries of humankind. In conclusion. We are all shocked by the horrific images of death from the Syrian civil war. Do you know how many victims the Syrian civil war has had during those seven years? 450,00 people have died. Due to vaccine unavailability in developing countries, hepatitis B alone kills 750,00 people every year, 300,00 of which die from liver cancer, a consequence of hepatitis B. Hepatitis B alone kills almost twice the people as the seven-year war in Syria. For many years, I practiced at a neonatal and children's Intensive Care Unit. I saw children like yours and mine die in a matter of hours from pneumococcus, meningococcus, measles. I saw babies born deaf or mentally disabled because their mother contracted rubella during her pregnancy. During this 15-minute speech, 80 children around the world were saved thanks to vaccinations. Never again, thanks to vaccines. Thank you. (Applause)

eMrFV2rnHlo.channel_description:
The Doctors is an Emmy award-winning daytime talk show hosted by ER physician Dr. Travis Stork and plastic surgeon Dr. Andrew Ordon.

The Doctors helps you understand the latest health headlines, such as the ice bucket challenge for ALS and the Ebola outbreak; delivers exclusive interviews with celebrities dealing with health issues, such as Teen Mom star Farrah Abraham, reality stars Honey Boo Boo and Mama June and activist Chaz Bono; brings you debates about health and safety claims from agricultural company Monsanto and celebrities such as Jenny McCarthy; and shows you the latest gross viral videos and explains how you can avoid an emergency situation. The Doctors also features the News in 2:00 digest of the latest celebrity health news and The Doctors’ Prescription for simple steps to get active, combat stress, eat better and live healthier.
eMrFV2rnHlo.description:
Subscribe to The Doctors: http://bitly.com/SubscribeTheDoctors
LIKE us on Facebook: http://bitly.com/TheDoctorsFacebook
Follow us on Twitter: http://bitly.com/TheDoctorsTwitter

For more, visit: http://thedoctorstv.com

The Doctors debate: As measles make a nationwide comeback, are parents who refuse to vaccinate their children contributing to the problem? Or are the vaccinations more dangerous than the disease itself? Barbara Loe Fisher, co-founder and president of the National Vaccine Information Center, shares the toll a vaccination allegedly took on her son Chris, who immediately after being vaccinated with a DPT shot suffered a convulsion, went into shock and lost consciousness. He was later diagnosed with brain damage and attention-deficit disorder.

This video will show you:
HOW TO discuss child vaccination
HOW TO talk to your doctor
HOW TO ask medical questions

TEDx is an international community that organizes TED-style events anywhere and everywhere -- celebrating locally-driven ideas and elevating them to a global stage. TEDx events are produced independently of TED conferences, each event curates speakers on their own, but based on TED's format and rules.

TED's videos may be used for non-commercial purposes under a Creative Commons License, Attribution–Non Commercial–No Derivatives (or the CC BY – NC – ND 4.0 International) and in accordance with our TED Talks Usage Policy (https://www.ted.com/about/our-organization/our-policies-terms/ted-talks-usage-policy). 

For more information on using TED for commercial purposes (e.g. employee learning, in a film or online course), please submit a Media Request here: https://media-requests.ted.com.
ggtkzkoI3eM.description:
Tara Haelle will focus on vaccine hesitancy and vaccine refusal. This is a global health threat that lurks unnoticed until it erupts into unpredictable disease outbreaks that are difficult to contain. She explains what underlies the fear and hesitancy that many people have toward vaccines, why it's not as irrational as some believe, and what's necessary to address it.

Tara Haelle is a freelance science and multimedia journalist who writes regularly at Forbes, NPR, Scientific American, Slate, Medscape, and other U.S.-based publications. She co-wrote “The Informed Parent: A Science-Based Guide to the First Four Years” with science journalist Emily Willingham, and she blogs about science and parenting at Red Wine & Applesauce. She holds a master's in photojournalism from the University of Texas at Austin and has published her images in several publications.

This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at http://ted.com/tedx
ggtkzkoI3eM.title: Why Parents Fear Vaccines | Tara Haelle | TEDxOslo

Mayo Clinic is a nonprofit worldwide leader in medical care, research and education for people from all walks of life. Doctors from every medical specialty work together to care for patients, joined by common systems and a philosophy of "the needs of the patient come first." Our headquarters are located in Rochester, MN while we have campuses in Jacksonville, FL and Arizona.

Learn more about Mayo Clinic's rich history, our locations and more at http://www.mayoclinic.org/about/

Get a detailed list of all our phone numbers at http://www.mayoclinic.org/contact/

Looking to connect with others facing similar health issues? Check out the new and improved Mayo Clinic Connect -- an online community where you can share your experiences, ask questions and find support from people like you.
